thread.title: Dusky trips in demand for stoat-trapping holiday-makers
thread.title_full: Dusky trips in demand for stoat-trapping holiday-makers

author: Phil McCarthy
title: Dusky trips in demand for stoat-trapping holiday-makers
text:
Dusky trips in demand for stoat-trapping holiday-makers PHIL MCCARTHY Last updated 14:12, July 22 2015 Supplied 
DOC and Real Journeys are looking for volunteers for an expedition to Dusky Sound - bird monitoring and stoat trapping work will be done. 
It might not be everyone's idea of a cruisy time, but the Department of Conservation says it has no problems filling spaces on a $1300-a-head working holiday in Dusky Sound. 
DOC and Real Journeys are looking for conservation-minded people for a discovery expedition to take part in the Dusky Sound Conservation and Restoration Programme. 
DOC relationship manager partnerships Kate Hebblethwaite said there were 30 spaces available for the conservation expedition and previous trips had been extremely popular. 
"I'm fully expecting this one to have great uptake as well." 
It was the first time the two organisations had undertaken a joint Dusky Sound expedition, and a proportion of the cruise would be donated to DOC's Dusky Sound conservation projects. 
The four day cruise will visit three of the remote islands â€“ Anchor, Indian and Long - where DOC is undertaking conservation work, and participants will be involved in tasks such as stoat trap checking and bird monitoring. In the evening they will hear from DOC staff about conservation projects in Dusky Sound. 
DOC conservation services manager Fiordland Lindsay Wilson said DOC had a vision to make Dusky Sound one of the most intact ecosystems in the world. 
"This joint venture between Real Journeys and DOC is a great way to show people first-hand some of the conservation work taking place in Dusky Sound to achieve that goal." 
The cruise includes a visit to Pigeon Island to see Richard Henry's historic site and Pickersgill Harbour, where Captain Cook moored his ship Resolution and set up an astronomer's observatory to fix the longitude and latitude of the headland, in 1773. 
All the elements of a Discovery Expedition on the Milford Wanderer would be included, Wilson said. 
The trip leaves from Manapouri on September 3 and includes a helicopter flight from West Arm to Supper Cove, Dusky Sound. The $1300 price-tag is 30 per cent off the normal price for a similar trip.
